content.title: G6PD Deficiency
content.summary: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is the most common human enzyme defect, affecting over 400 million people worldwide. This X-linked disorder renders RBCs vulnerable to oxidative stress by impairing glutathione regeneration. Hemolysis occurs episodically upon exposure to oxidative triggers (infections, fava beans, certain drugs) rather than chronically.
key_points: Most common enzyme deficiency worldwide; X-linked recessive
Episodic hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress (drugs, infections, fava beans)
Bite cells and Heinz bodies on peripheral smear
G6PD levels may be falsely normal during acute hemolysis - retest in 2-3 months
Treatment is avoidance of triggers; no specific therapy
Confers partial protection against severe malaria
content.statement: G6PD deficiency is an X-linked disorder of the hexose monophosphate shunt that impairs RBC antioxidant defense, causing episodic intravascular hemolysis upon exposure to oxidative stressors, diagnosed by enzyme assay and managed by trigger avoidance.

explanation.intuition: G6PD is like the fire extinguisher in RBCs - it generates NADPH to refill the glutathione 'extinguisher' that neutralizes oxidative 'fires.' Without enough G6PD, oxidative stress from drugs, infections, or foods overwhelms the RBC, causing hemoglobin to denature (Heinz bodies) and the cell to rupture.
explanation.key_insight: During acute hemolysis, younger RBCs (with higher G6PD activity) survive while older, G6PD-depleted RBCs lyse. This enriches the circulation with young RBCs, causing falsely normal G6PD assay during crisis - always retest 2-3 months after hemolytic episode.
explanation.technical_details: G6PD catalyzes the first step of the hexose monophosphate shunt: Glucose-6-phosphate → 6-phosphogluconolactone, generating NADPH. NADPH is essential for glutathione reductase to regenerate reduced glutathione (GSH), which detoxifies hydrogen peroxide and other oxidants. Over 200 G6PD variants exist, with different degrees of enzyme instability and clinical severity.

definitions_glossary.G6PD: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase; enzyme in hexose monophosphate shunt generating NADPH
definitions_glossary.hexose_monophosphate_shunt: Alternative name for pentose phosphate pathway; generates NADPH in RBCs
definitions_glossary.NADPH: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (reduced); essential cofactor for glutathione reduction
definitions_glossary.glutathione: Tripeptide antioxidant; reduced form (GSH) neutralizes reactive oxygen species
definitions_glossary.Heinz_bodies: Denatured hemoglobin inclusions seen with supravital staining (crystal violet)
definitions_glossary.bite_cells: RBCs with semicircular membrane defects where Heinz bodies were removed by spleen
definitions_glossary.oxidative_stress: Imbalance between reactive oxygen species production and antioxidant defenses
definitions_glossary.favism: Hemolytic crisis triggered by fava bean ingestion in G6PD-deficient individuals
definitions_glossary.intravascular_hemolysis: RBC destruction within bloodstream with hemoglobinuria
definitions_glossary.X_linked_recessive: Inheritance pattern affecting primarily males; females are carriers
definitions_glossary.methemoglobin: Oxidized hemoglobin unable to carry oxygen; can accumulate in severe G6PD deficiency
definitions_glossary.primaquine: Antimalarial drug; classic trigger of hemolysis in G6PD deficiency

pathophysiology.mechanism: G6PD deficiency → Reduced NADPH generation → Impaired glutathione regeneration → Oxidative damage to hemoglobin and membrane → Heinz body formation → Intravascular and extravascular hemolysis

genetics.affected: Primarily males; heterozygous females may have variable expression due to lyonization

variants.Class_II: Severe deficiency (<10% activity) - Mediterranean, Asian variants
variants.Class_III: Moderate deficiency (10-60% activity) - African A- variant

pathophysiology.protective_effect: Confers partial resistance to severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria

triggers.infections: Most common trigger - viral, bacterial, sepsis

clinical_presentation.neonatal_jaundice: G6PD is common cause of severe neonatal hyperbilirubinemia in endemic areas

G6PD_enzyme_assay.timing: Best performed 2-3 months after hemolytic episode
G6PD_enzyme_assay.caveat: May be falsely normal during/after crisis due to young RBC enrichment
G6PD_enzyme_assay.interpretation: Low activity confirms diagnosis; normal does not exclude during recovery

diagnostic_test.genetic_testing: Available for confirmation and carrier detection

acute_crisis.remove_trigger: Stop offending drug, treat underlying infection
supportive: Hydration to maintain renal blood flow
Transfusion if severe anemia (Hgb <7 g/dL or symptomatic)
acute_crisis.avoid: Oxidant drugs even during recovery period

prevention.education: Provide list of drugs/foods to avoid
prevention.screening: Consider before prescribing known trigger drugs
prevention.medical_alert: Bracelet or card for emergency situations

treatment_options.chronic_management: Most patients are asymptomatic between episodes; no maintenance therapy needed

definition.@value: An X-linked enzymatic disorder affecting the hexose monophosphate shunt, causing episodic hemolytic anemia upon exposure to oxidative stressors due to impaired RBC antioxidant defense

scopeNote.@value: Most common enzyme deficiency worldwide; confers malaria protection

medicalCode.description: Anemia due to glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency

learning_objectives: Explain the biochemical basis of G6PD deficiency and its role in RBC antioxidant defense
Identify common triggers of hemolytic crises in G6PD deficiency
Recognize characteristic peripheral smear findings (bite cells, Heinz bodies)
Describe why G6PD enzyme levels may be normal during acute hemolysis
List drugs contraindicated in G6PD deficiency
clinical_pearls: G6PD enzyme assay may be falsely normal during crisis - retest in 2-3 months
Bite cells + Heinz bodies + hemoglobinuria after drug/infection = G6PD deficiency
Most common trigger is infection, not drugs
African A- variant has milder hemolysis than Mediterranean variants
Check G6PD before prescribing primaquine, dapsone, or rasburicase
Confers partial malaria protection (explains high prevalence in endemic areas)
common_misconceptions: G6PD deficiency causes chronic hemolysis - it's episodic (except rare Class I variants)
Normal G6PD level rules out deficiency - not during or after acute crisis
Only men are affected - heterozygous females can have symptomatic episodes
